variant.question: After the departure of a VFR flight from an aerodrome, one of the passengers feels very sick so the captain decides to return to the airfield. Which of the following phrases should be used in this case?

options.text: Pan Pan Pan Pan Pan Pan, Stuttgart Information, Fastair 123, due to sick passenger, returning to Stuttgart, position 15 NM north of Stuttgart, FL110.
Pan Pan Pan Pan Pan Pan, Stuttgart Information, Fastair 123, position 15 NM north of Stuttgart, FL110, due to sick passenger, returning to Stuttgart.
Pan Pan Pan Pan Pan Pan, Stuttgart Information, Fastair 123, returning to Stuttgart, due to sick passenger, position 15 NM north of Stuttgart, FL110.
Pan Pan Pan Pan Pan Pan, Fastair 123, Stuttgart Information, position 15 NM north of Stuttgart, FL110, returning to Stuttgart, due to sick passenger.

Pan Pan Pan Pan Pan Pan Medical, Stuttgart Information, Fastair 123, returning to Stuttgart, due to sick passenger, position 15 NM north of Stuttgart, FL110.
Pan Pan Pan Pan Pan Pan, Fastair 123, Stuttgart Information, position 15 NM north of Stuttgart, FL110, returning to Stuttgart, due to sick passenger.
Pan Pan Pan Pan Pan Pan, Stuttgart Information, Fastair 123, position 15 NM north of Stuttgart, FL110, due to sick passenger, returning to Stuttgart.

variant.question: An aircraft encountering radio communication failure on an IFR flight in IMC has to land, if possible, within

options.text: 30 minutes after the ETA or the last acknowledged EAT, whichever is later.
15 minutes of the ETA as stated in the current IFR flight plan, or hold at a designated navigation fix.
30 minutes after noticing the radio communication failure and squawking the appropriate SSR transponder code.
15 minutes after crossing the designated navigation fix from which a normal instrument approach can be conducted.

variant.question: An aircraft encountering radio communication failure on an IFR flight in IMC has to land, if possible, within...

options.text: 30 minutes after ETA or the last EAT, whichever is later.

15 minutes after vacating the transition layer.

variant.question:
The radio frequency spectrum contains several bands
Which of the following statements is completely correct about the band normally used for the Aeronautical Mobile Service voice communications?

options.text: It is situated two bands below the SHF band and contains frequency 288.0 MHz.
It is immediately above the MF band and its frequencies are measured in MHz.
It is called the VLF band and contains frequency 130.450 kHz.
It is immediately below the UHF band and its frequencies are measured in kHz.

variant.question: The radio frequency spectrum contains several bands. Which of the following statements is completely correct about the band normally used for the Aeronautical Mobile Service voice communications?

options.text: The band just below UHF and it includes 288 MHz.
It is immediately below the UHF band and its frequencies are measured in kHz.
It is situated two bands below the SHF band and its frequencies are measured in kHz.
It is immediately above the MF band and its frequencies are measured in MHz.

variant.question:
Consider the European Regulations on Air Operations
 Which of the following statements correctly describes the radio communication equipment required for operations under IFR?

options.text: The radio communication equipment must be in accordance with the applicable airspace requirements and include at least two independent radio communication systems.
There must be at least one radio communication system and it must be in accordance with the applicable airspace requirements.
The radio communication equipment must be capable of one- or two-way communication, meeting the communication requirements in defined portions of airspace.
There must be at least one radio communication system and it must be in accordance with the applicable certification requirements.

variant.question: What is ATIS and what should a pilot expect from it?

options.text: Automatic Terminal Information Service, providing information about weather, runway, and type of approach to be expected.
Aerodrome Traffic Indication Service, providing information about the times that other aircraft are expected to take off and land.
Aerodrome Terminal Instruction Service, providing routing instructions for instrument approaches.
Airborne Traffic Information Service, providing information about the position of other aircraft in the vicinity.

variant.question: Which are the radio frequency bands normally used for aeronautical radio communications?

options.text: VHF and HF.
LF and VHF.
VHF and MF.
UHF and VHF.

options.text: Aircraft call sign, nature of distress, pilot`s intention, present position, level and heading.
Nature of distress, aircraft call sign, present position, aerodrome of destination, assistance required
Nature of distress, aircraft call sign, aerodrome of departure, position and level, pilot`s intention.

options.text: Aircraft call sign, nature of distress, pilot`s intention, present position, level and heading.

variant.question: What phrase shall be used in the event of a disruption of communication for which it has been identified that the receiver is the cause of the malfunction?

options.text: Transmitting blind due to receiver failure.
Communicating blind due to radio failure.
Blind transmission.
Blind emission.

variant.question: What is the consequence of a microphone button stuck on transmit (switched on)?

options.text: The frequency can not be used by others.
Readability will improve for all stations.
Other stations will have to use the WORD TWICE technique.
None.

variant.question: Approaching the Top of Climb (TOC) on an IFR flight, a pilot suffers a total loss of communications. The aircraft is currently in VMC conditions. What will be the next course of action?

options.text: Continue to fly in VMC, proceed to land at the nearest suitable aerodrome and report the arrival to the appropriate Air Traffic Services unit as soon as possible.
Continue to fly the flight planned route, hold at the initial approach fix until the estimated approach time, then proceed to commence an instrument approach at the destination aerodrome.
Continue to fly in VMC, proceed to land at the destination aerodrome and report the arrival to the appropriate Air Traffic Services unit as soon as possible.
Continue to fly in VMC or IMC, proceed to land at an aerodrome that provides radar services.

variant.question:
Approaching the Top of Climb (TOC) on an IFR flight, a pilot suffers a total loss of communications. The aircraft is currently in VMC conditions
 What will be the next course of action?

options.text: Continue to fly in VMC, proceed to land at the nearest suitable aerodrome and report the arrival to the appropriate Air Traffic Services unit as soon as possible.
Continue to fly in VMC, proceed to land at the destination aerodrome and report the arrival to the appropriate Air Traffic Services unit as soon as possible.
Continue to fly the flight planned route, hold at the initial approach fix until the estimated approach time, then proceed to commence an instrument approach at the destination aerodrome.
Continue to fly in VMC or IMC, proceed to land at an aerodrome that provides radar services.

variant.question: An aircraft experiencing radio communication failure on an IFR flight in VMC should..

options.text: land at the nearest suitable aerodrome.
land at the destination aerodrome.
land at the alternate aerodrome.
return to the aerodrome of departure.

variant.question: An aircraft experiencing radio communication failure on an IFR flight in VMC should..

options.text: continue to fly in VMC, land at the nearest suitable aerodrome, and report its arrival.
leave controlled airspace and continue the flight within uncontrolled airspace.
continue the flight to destination aerodrome.
squawk IDENT and proceed to the alternate aerodrome.

variant.question: An aircraft experiencing radio communication failure on an IFR flight in IMC should..

options.text: proceed in accordance with the current flight plan to the designated navigation aid serving the destination aerodrome.
divert to the most suitable aerodrome according to the route of flight.
execute a VMC approach at the nearest suitable aerodrome.
proceed to an area from where the flight can be continued according to the visual flight rules.

variant.question: A pilot is under radar control, flying in IMC, and has just reached the cleared altitude. 8 NM before the mandatory reporting point he/she suddenly suffers a radio failure, and sets the appropriate SSR code. Given the sequence of events, how long must the pilot maintain the last cleared altitude or minimum flight altitude (whichever is higher)?

options.text: 7 minutes from failing to report at a the compulsory report point.
12 minutes from reaching the last cleared altitude.
7 minutes from setting the SSR code.
12 minutes from setting the SSR code.

12 minutes from setting the SSR code.

A pilot in flight hears an urgency message on an area control frequency that is acknowledged by the area controller. What action must the pilot take?

options.text: Take care not to interfere with the transmission of the urgency traffic.
Write down the information being transmitted and re-transmit it on the emergency frequency 121.5 MHz.
Immediately stop all transmissions on the frequency being used by the urgency traffic.
Immediately inform the controller of his/her position in order to provide assistance if necessary.

variant.question:

 What action must the pilot take?

options.text: Take care not to interfere with the transmission of the urgency traffic.
Immediately stop all transmissions on the frequency being used by the urgency traffic.
Immediately inform the controller of his/her position in order to provide assistance if necessary.
Write down the information being transmitted and re-transmit it on the emergency frequency 121.5 MHz.

The waves are reflected at the ionosphere at the height of about 100 km and reach the earth surface in the form of sky-waves
Similar to short waves with practically no atmospheric disturbance
